subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|尹|口|ls=psc|ls2=ic|c1=p|c2=s|t1=(hand holding a rod) to administer|t2=mouth}}. In the oracle bones and early Zhou bronze inscriptions, {{zh-l|君}} was often interchanged with {{zh-l|*尹}}. ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' suggests that {{zh-l|*口}} represents commands, but it may simply be decorative.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
; “lord; prince”
: {{unk|zh}}. Here are several possibilities:
:* Related to {{cog|omx||kmin}}, {{m|omx||kmun|to exercise royal power; to be king; to reign}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}});
:* Related to {{och-l|尹|director; governor}} and {{och-l|元|head}} and cognate with {{cog|bo|མགོན||protector; master; lord}} ({{zh-ref|Mei Tsu-lin, 1985}});
:* The ''*k-'' prefixed derivative of {{och-l|尹|to straighten; to administer}} ({{zh-ref|Baxter and Sagart, 1998}}); however, this is phonologically problematic ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

; ACG sense
: {{obor|zh|ja|-}} {{m|ja|君|tr=-kun}}.

subSections.title: Suffix
Usage notes
subSections.text:
* There is no direct translation in English – as with other Japanese honorifics, it might roughly correspond to [[dear]], as in “your dear father”.
* Respectful suffixes also serve to indicate whose relative is in question: rather than “my father” and “your father”, one would say {{m|ja|父|tr=chichi||[[father]]}} and {{m|ja|父君|tr=chichi-gimi||dear father}}.
* Used of nobles. Attaches to close family relationship nouns such as {{m|ja|母|tr=haha||[[mother]]}}, {{m|ja|姉|tr=ane||sister}}, {{m|ja|姫|tr=hime||[[daughter]] of a [[noble]] [[family]], [[princess]]}}.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Usage notes
subSections.text: ''-kun'' is often used as a suffix when calling someone. The listener is lower or the same level in social position and is often, but not always, male.
